timeline.bodyText:
Some of the above mappings don't look right to me. TIME should be TIME, TIMESTAMP  should be TIMESTAMP, and TIMESTAMPTZ should probably be TIMESTAMP_WITH_TIMEZONE (but I'm not sure about that, we need to check).
And INTERVAL I'm not sure about but I'm pretty sure it's not a DATE.

timeline.bodyText: I don't think it's necessary to have name() (or a ColumnDescriptor at all for that matter) since the column name is already available through SqlResult#columnNames(). Instead, could we just add a SqlResult#jdbcTypes() method?

timeline.bodyText: I'm still a bit unclear on how the JDBCType will be used. Is it OK that I'm overriding some of the expected JDBCTypes for DB2 here? Or is it important that all DBs are consistent with one another for this use case? CC @gavinking
timeline.author: aguibert

replies.bodyText: Well we’re going to use it to decide what kind of Java object to read from that column of the result set. For example, if you return Types.VARCHAR, we will read strings.
replies.author: gavinking

replies.bodyText: So for testChar, in DB2 the column is defined as CHAR(6). To me it seemed correct that we classify that as JDBCType.CHAR, but since a char[6] is basically the same thing as VARCHAR/String, should I have it return JDBCType.VARCHAR for a CHAR(6) column?
replies.author: aguibert

replies.bodyText: I would just try to copy what the JDBC driver does.
replies.author: gavinking

replies.bodyText:
@gavinking what can we assume among these ?

same java type => the same SQL type?
same java type <= the same SQL type?
same java type <=> the same SQL type?
no relationship ?
replies.author: vietj

replies.bodyText:
No it's nonsimple. If you look at the appendices of the JDBC spec you'll see that it's a many-to-many mapping between Java types and SQL spec types. And then the Hibernate built-in types only loosely follow that mapping.
But that's not what we're trying to capture here. What we're going for here is a mapping from database types to equivalent ANSI SQL types. Now that is also nonsimple, but it's simpler, and we can look at what mapping the JDBC drivers use for inspiration.
replies.author: gavinking

replies.bodyText: (But of course Hibernate does expect some consistency: if you return TIMESTAMP, it's going to expect to get a LocalDateTime when it reads the result set, and if you return TIMESTAMP_WITH_TIMEZONE, it's going to expect to get an OffsetDateTime.)
replies.author: gavinking

timeline.bodyText: @vietj we should check what the JDBC driver does here. the whole NUMERIC vs DECIMAL thing has always been a source of problems since the drivers are pretty inconsistent here.

replies.bodyText: @BillyYccc can you check that against the JDBC driver ?
replies.author: vietj

replies.bodyText: it is DECIMAL in this case and we should correct this, see https://github.com/mysql/mysql-connector-j/blob/dbd865c9fc68701efc70197ea1e65002520bed91/src/main/protocol-impl/java/com/mysql/cj/protocol/a/NativeProtocol.java#L1423 (both constants unsigned and signed then reference the Types.DECIMAL = 3 constant)
replies.author: vietj

replies.bodyText:
so if that's an array, how do you get the array component ? I'm assuming now in case of array that we return the component type of the array.
we could add on ColumnDescriptor an isArray or isMultivalued boolean
replies.author: vietj

replies.bodyText: TBH I have never used a SQL array type in my life, so i'm just not sure, but it would not surprise me if there was no good way, other than calling Array.getBaseType().
replies.author: gavinking

replies.bodyText: I added a ColumnDescriptor.isArray method to check whether it's an array and the SQL type will be in this case the component type of the array.
replies.author: vietj
